title: CBD fees would cut traffic by 40pc in Sydney, Melbourne
text:
"It would lead to a better allocation of road space to those who most need it; it isn’t excessively expensive to implement – in fact, it would contribute to government coffers; and in the longer term it would encourage households and employers to make more sensible decisions about where to locate."

A number of economic experts, including the 2009 Henry tax review, have called for some form of road user charging to tackle congestion, as well as deal more broadly with the hit to fuel excise revenue that comes from greater adoption of electric vehicles.

However, Urban Infrastructure Minister Alan Tudge ruled out road user charging at The Australian Financial Review National Infrastructure Summit in June, saying the government's focus instead was to spend money on improving roads to ease congestion.

The Grattan Institute's Transport and Cities Program director Marion Terrill said it was opportune to re-examine the matter.

Infrastructure splurge

Her report points out that big investments in public transport have been a hallmark of recent election victories. The Andrews Labor government promised to spend $72 billion on public transport at the 2018 Victorian election, the Berejiklian Liberal government pledged $42 billion at the 2019 NSW election and the Morrison government $13 billion at the May election.

Sydney's major projects include the city and western Sydney metro lines and rail link to the under construction western Sydney airport. Melbourne's big ticket projects are the suburban rail loop and airport link.

As well as public transport alternatives, the institute's report said technological advances such as in-car electronic tags and automatic number plate recognition have made it easier to levy congestion charges.

The institute also claims public resistance to congestion charging is not as bad as governments, pointing to experiences in other cities where it has been embraced as motorists realise the benefits of fewer cars on the road.

The report rejects claims a congestion charge is unfair by unduly hitting poorer motorists, saying the median income for a full-time worker who drives into Sydney's CBD is $2450 a week and $1980 in Melbourne.

Industry group Infrastructure Partnerships Australia rejected Grattan's call for a CBD cordon, claiming it did not reflect the conditions motorists in Sydney and Melbourne faced.

"Most of the vehicle kilometres in Sydney and Melbourne are actually travelled outside of the CBD," the organisation said.

"As a result, a CBD-based cordon charge would not be an effective mechanism to institute behaviour change and therefore reduced congestion.

"Only a whole-of-network charging system provides a solution to the twofold problem of congestion and funding. A whole-of-network charge provides for unified charging of vehicles across the whole network that goes beyond a city cordon."
description: Modelling by the Grattan Institute suggests charging motorists to enter Sydney and Melbourne CBDs would reduce traffic by 40 per cent in the morning peak.
